Award.AwardTitle: The Environmental Sustainability of Integrated Solid Waste Management in a Carbon Constrained World

Division.LongName: Div Of Chem, Bioeng, Env, & Transp Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
The goal of this research is to model the effect of greenhouse gas mitigation policies on management of municipal solid waste (MSW) and to determine the MSW management practices that reduce greenhouse gases most cost-effectively without increasing other environmental impacts. In the US, solid waste management represents 13% of non-energy related greenhouse gas emissions and landfills are the second largest source of anthropogenic methane. The research approach integrates cost aspects of solid waste management, environmental life-cycle impacts of solid waste management, and greenhouse gas mitigation policies. This problem is complex, and the approach is a comprehensive blending of the science and engineering of solid waste management and the economics of GHG mitigation policies. Results will have broader impact through the release of the models via the World Wide Web.


Bruce K. Hamilton
6/28/10

POR.DRECONTENT:
Solid waste management (SWM) represents a critical aspect of civil infrastructure, and must adapt to changing energy and environmental policies, waste compositions, and energy systems. Given the complexity of SWM systems, rigorous analysis of system response under different future scenarios requires a sophisticated modeling framework that links detailed process-level operations to an aggregate SWM strategy. It is necessary to understand in detail how unit processes such as waste collection, material recovery facilities, landfills, and waste-to-energy facilities can be optimized in a systems context to meet goals related to cost, emissions, and waste diversion. Looking ahead, SWM systems must proactively adapt to changing waste composition, policy requirements, and an evolving energy system to cost-effectively and sustainably manage future solid waste.

The primary research objectives were to: (1) evaluate changes over time in optimal technology selections for individual SWM processes (e.g., collection, landfills, composting); (2) identify cost-effective, process-level responses to GHG policies; (3) generate and examine integrated SWM strategies (i.e., waste material flows and process choices) that would most effectively respond to different GHG policies; (4) identify and evaluate the interdependent effects of specific policies designed to influence SWM in a GHG-regulated environment; and (5) analyze the effects of GHG policies on other environmental emissions and impacts associated with integrated SWM strategies.

These research objectives were met through the development and application of the Solid Waste Optimization Life-cycle Framework (SWOLF). SWOLF is an open source modeling framework that links the detailed unit process models within a modeling framework that can optimize solid waste strategies under different future scenarios (go.ncsu.edu/swolf). SWOLF has three critical features. First, it is a life cycle model, and can therefore track the costs, emissions, and environmental impacts from waste generation through final disposal or energy and material recovery. Second, it can optimize the waste mass flows and unit process capacities over time in order to meet user-defined objectives. Third, SWOLF can consider changes to the broader energy system through time-varying fuel prices, electricity prices, electricity generation mix, and vehicle fuel economy.

SWOLF and its associated process models have been used to analyze the cost and environmental emissions from present and future SWM strategies. The application of SWOLF has resulted in useful insights that are relevant to policy formulation and the response of SWM systems to future policies. For example, results showed that GHG emissions may increase with increasing landfill diversion; thus, SWM decision makers should consider the actual environmental impacts they wish to reduce instead of focusing on the potentially misleading proxy of landfill diversion. Results also indicated that changing waste composition and energy systems can significantly affect life-cycle costs and performance, and therefore SWM life-cycle modeling should consider such future changes to develop robust, policy relevant recommendations.
 
The results have been disseminated through several manuscripts, multiple conference presentations, and workshops. This work has provided interdisciplinary research opportunities for several graduate and undergraduate research assistants, and has included collaborations with the Technical University of Denmark and the University of Novi Sad. A simplified SWOLF educational tool has been developed for use in introductory courses in environmental science.
